sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying ring
message_1: What is the magnetic field strength at the center of a circular loop of wire with a radius of 0.1 meters and a current of 2 amps flowing through it?
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field strength at the center of a circular loop of wire, we can use the formula:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * π * r)

where B is the magnetic field strength, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) T·m/A), I is the current flowing through the wire (2 A), and r is the radius of the loop (0.1 m).

B = (4π × 10^(-7) T·m/A * 2 A) / (2 * π * 0.1 m)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) T·m) / (0.2π m)

B = 4 × 10^(-6) T

The magnetic field strength at the center of the circular loop of wire is 4 × 10^(-6) Tesla.
